comments.commentBody: David Stern will not permit this to happen.  He required Dolan to hire Walsh, and he will prevent him from re-hiring Thomas.  End of story.
What's most terrifying about this piece is the fact that Dolan is that much of a tosser to rehire Thomas.

Those of us who still love the sport of "kings" have to be grateful for the opportunity to have seen  the incredible Zenyatta make history.  We owe tremendous thanks to her owners for keeping her on the track for the sake of the sport.  I shed a few tears with Mike Smith tonight, but I am especially glad that she was not injured.  Her soundness will manifest itself through the breeding shed and make the sport better in the future,  I have vivid memories of  watching Secretariat and always wondered what it must have been like to see Man of War, Seabiscuit, Citation, and other greats in person.  Now I know, and what a privilege.  Thank you Jerry and Ann Moss, John Sherriff and Mike Smith.  Thanks, too, to Zenyatta's faithful groom, who was so protective of Zenyatta today when she was clearly reacting to a unprecedented level of noise.  Anyone can see that ALL of you love that great horse very much.  Have a Guinness, Queen Z, you surely earned it today.
Clever theme, though some answers were better than others.  UNDER A TACK was great, as was CHECKING A COUNT.  EVENING A TIRE didn't cut it.

As a long time solver, relatively recent lurker to the blog, and first time poster, I was disappointed to see the negative comments re GLADSOME - a perfectly fine adjective.  "What the  GLADSOME tidings be which inspire your heav'nly song?" , part of my favorite Christmas carol.

@Bev (and Patricia, and all the other dog-lovers), my oldest dog turns 16 this month.  I've been preparing to lose her for quite a while now, but I know I will never be truly prepared.  I lost my girl Allie to congestive heart failure 2 years ago and still think about her all the time.  As Will Rogers said, "If there are no dogs in heaven, then when I die I want to go where they went."  I'm in no rush to go!  But if there is such a place I know I'll be in the very best company.
Look at that. My solve was interrupted, and I came back to finish the job two days later. So it was a clue earlier in the week. :-) Thanks, Steve.
STIES is not from earlier in the week.  It's 34D.

Nice puzzle.  16D was good because of the double meaning of the first word, but 36A was my favorite of the theme answers.  Had that pesky U at first in 97A, but fortunately the crossing made the mistake obvious.  Tried several wrong guesses for 38D before landing on the right one, and let the crosses take care of some of the more obscure words like 126D.  Didn't like 28D, seems forced.

I guess a few had trouble with the NW. For me, I had no trouble with 3/4ths of the puzzle but that remaining quarter was impossible! Even after revealing three or four words, I still couldn't finish.

So I crumpled that one up and now I'm ready for Sunday,

-- jpgaskell

I'm probably too late for all, since tomorrow's puzzle is already up, but I, too, want to offer condolenses to Bev. To quote a recent past president, I feel your pain. I've been there, with several cats and only 1 dog. There's nothing to match the total, uncritical love you can get from pets. I'm so sorry.

My solving experience was unaffected by the "unlocking" of the puzzles. It was the discovery of the blog that changed everything for me! In the past, I would set aside a puzzle I hadn't finished and go back to it repeatedly, sometimes for several days, until I got it. But once I discovered this blog, I can no longer wait! I quit earlier than I used to so I can go see what everyone else's experience was like. And I like getting Mr. HP when I'm done, so I know I'm truly done.

I have been an annual visitor to St. Maarten for more than 20 years and would like to make a few addenda to the Times piece of 11/7/10.
Yes, the Caribbean sun is soothing, the beaches are blissful, and restaurants are charming and plentiful, but there are also many problems.
Traffic on St. Maarten has become a bear. Continuing overdevelopment combined with the lack of space on the island and the inability to construct additional roads has resulted in worsening daily gridlock, especially near the airport, where the opening of the Simpson Bay drawbridge regularly brings traffic to 20-minute standstills.
Petty crime is also a serious problem. If you leave anything of value in your parked car in Phillipsburg or Marigot it can, and will, be broken into. This is especially true at the beaches. Once my car was broken into at a beach because I had left a six-pack of beer on the back seat. The thieves smashed a window and helped themselves. Oddly, only two of the cans were taken. Experience has shown that, if one must visit a remote beach, the best policy is to leave the car unlocked, with nothing in it. At least then you might not be driving away with a broken window.

The 14-Across clue says "Annapolis frosh", but the answer is "plebe."  Last I checked, Annapolis was the home of the US Naval Academy, whose first-year students are "midshipmen," and plebes go to West Point (U.S. Military Academy).  Who fact-checks these clues?

Well, what do you know?  I learn something new every day.  Thanks, Cranky Vermonter, for setting me straight.  Yes, I'd have a bunch o' nickels to my name by now as well...  leave it to Mr. Shortz to never be wrong.

comments.userDisplayName: Phil in the mountains of Kyushu
comments.commentBody:
Love your subordinate clauses, Mo.

Constantly here you give Geo. W. the benefit of his fantasies in your main clauses, as if, like some rube Mark Twain, you're open to whatever lightning rod salesman who might walk by. (See Twain's masterpiece on this, "Political Economy.")

But each time you set yourself up for credulity, the sentence opens also to the plausibilities of alternative reality -- in this case true reality -- delivered by deft subordinates: relative clauses, adverbial phrases, and similes.

Nice. Textbook teachable. Or do kids in schools learn anymore to write, or think, or make human or any other connection -- or do anything other than prep for more standardized tests, or more inundations of narrow info in bunker departments?

If we still lived in a democratic republic instead of the corporatist state our nation has become, Bush, Cheney, etc. would have been impeached and put on trial for war crimes. Instead, we had Nancy Pelosi exclaiming that "impeachment was off the table" after the Democrats regained control of Congress. It was only fitting that the cowardly, Blue Dog Democrats were thrown out of office last Tuesday. Liberal Democrats were also defeated showing that when you betray the interests of the working and middle classes, and sell out to corporations, the "blowback" is inevitable.

George Bush famously gave up the booze years before he entered the White House. I'm not sure why he bothered, other than that his wife demanded it. Your recitation of "Decision Points" makes it seem that a better title would have been "My Eight Years in a Fog."

Bush doesn't seem to have been aware of anything, even when the information appeared on the front page of the New York Times, dictated by one of his top staff. Perhaps the big question readers of Bush's memoir should ask is, why were West Wing & Pentagon staff giving Judith Miller classified information they wouldn't share with the President of the United States?

The Constant Weader at www.RealityChex.com

Awww, Maureen, still piling on like so many ... yes, it is all George W. Bush's fault.  The relentless effort to spend money we didn't/don't have and the deregulation which led to the wall street greed games all happened on his watch, didn't they?  The left needs someone and who better to blame than "W?"  And, he campaigned so relentlessly for Republicans in this just past election. Blame on, blame on.

This is what happens when a C-student becomes president.  When are we going to realize that complicated jobs require smart people?  You wouldn’t take your car to an unqualified mechanic because he’s “an average Joe.”  You wouldn’t let an unlicensed surgeon operate on you because you think he’d be a “nice guy to have a beer with.”  But many Americans apparently think that piloting the ship of state does not require a driver’s license, much less any special training.  When you realize that the former president of the United States has written more books than he’s read, you may get an inkling of why we’re now in something of a quagmire.

maureen...your recent columns, like this one, have been smart and sometimes funny. and serious. they are an improvement over the rut you've been in for some time.

please continue.

a trenchant and treacly but laser precise reading of Bush's attempt to change the narrative about his legacy which is coming at the same time as this country, bereft of any wisdom learned from recent history, tries to recreate a new government crafted of the basest traits of intolerance, xenophobia and anti-intellectualism. this  is just sad.

Maureen I'm so glad you've enjoyed Dubya's memoir so much. Was it written in crayon and did Dubya remember to stay in lines? Was it longer than My Pet Goat?

Sorry but there's nothing particularly endearing about reliving eight long years of Dubya. The botched up election of 2000 ended up with 5 Supreme Court justices appointed by Republicans Corporate Shill Reagan and Bush 41 surrendering to keys to the White House the one person they considered the rightful heir to the throne, Bush the Younger. After all, it was the only rational decision after 8 years of William Jefferson Clinton who was still regarded as an uncouth peasant who hijacked the White House from its rightful aristocratic owners.

Personally I'm not remotely interested in Dubya's attempt at revisionist history where he re-invents himself as the noble and decisive hero who saved America from a fate worse than death. But I do find it a bit odd that Maureen's book report omits the key defining event of the whole Bush presidency--the terrorist attacks of September 11, 2001. That's almost like reading A Night To Remember and ignoring the part where the Titanic collides with the iceberg.

How come? Do you really miss Dubya that much Maureen that you're going to give him a pass on the worst disaster in modern American history!!!!????

Bush only looks so good, in restrospect, because Obama looks so awful, today.  If we had an intelligent competent President, right now; Bush would still look like the big spending , big-government statist he really was.  If Obama keeps going the way he is going, Bush will soon like like Geroge Washington, by comparison

The Decider was great on his Bike,
But Horseback riding did not like,
In the Vietnam War, he,
Busy politic'lly,
Did not seek a preemptive strike.

Someone please tell Maureen that George W. Bush is no longer President and that President Obama, in trying to implement his socialistic policies, has created his own mess of which Maureen is now trying to blame others.

It is amusing that the NY Times pays Maureen to be President Obama's cheerleader and then it wonders why its circulation is going down. Once again, Ms. Dowd shows her extremist liberal and bias side in her writing.

Bush's comments about Kanye West this week reveals to us the true character and maturity of our former president, not a ghost written hagiography. The tragedies of 9/11, Iraq War, Katrina, and economic collapse all pale in his mind to a now five years old comment from the rapper.

For comparison recall teenage singer Taylor Swift's response to Kanye: "Whatever".
